titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. My brother and his wife were here a few minutes this afternoon— Mrs: Adams, with Caroline, and the children went out to Dr: Welsh’s. The Club were at my house in the Evening, and every member, excepting Dr: Howard attended— They are now Mr: S. Cobb— Judge Davis, Judge Dawes, Dr: Dexter, Dr: Eliot, Mr: Emerson, Mr: Edward Gray— Dr: Howard— Dr: Kirkland— Mr: Smith, Dr: Spooner, Mr: Tyng and Dr: Warren— Though somewhat interrupted by this occurrence, I wrote my usual task for my lecture.

2. I called upon Mr: Jackson this morning the Treasurer of the College, and received of him a check on the Bank; after a proposition from him to pay me in depreciated bills to which I did not think proper to assent— At 12. O’Clock I met the town’s Commissioners concerning the Mill-Pond, and sat with them untill 2.— We considered the Proposals from the Corporation and agreed to some modification of our own to be proposed again to them— Mr: John Smith came into town from Quincy. In the Evening there was a large party at Mr: B. Joy’s—to which I accompanied Caroline— And was there towards the close of the Evening, myself.

3. Walked to Cambridge, with John Smith— At 10. I read my 20th: Lecture— Attended afterwards a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse— Pass’d an hour in the library— Dined at the Drs: though he and his Lady went into Boston— At 2. I attended the Declamation which was far superior to any that I have yet heard— I returned to Boston in the Stage, and met the Commissioners of the Mill-Pond—proceeded further upon the business with them—adjourned about 7. in the Evening. Dr: Welsh and his Lady spent the Evening with us.

4. Independence Day.— My father and mother came to town early this morning— At 9 10. O’Clock there was a procession, of the Governor and Council, together with a party invited by them from the Senate-chamber in the State-house to the Brattle-Street Meeting house; where a Prayer and an address were delivered by Dr: Baldwin the Chaplain of the Legislature. the procession afterwards returned to the Council-chamber, and took a Collation provided at the expense of the State. I returned with them, but having accompanied my children to the Church had not been in the procession thither— At 12 O’Clock the Selectmen, with Company invited by them formed a second procession, which I also attended to the Old South Church, where a prayer was made by Dr: Lathrop, and a very good Oration delivered by Mr: Peter Thacher— After this a third procession was form’d from the State House to Faneuil-Hall, where numerous company dined, by a private subscription, with their guests— I had declined subscribing to this dinner, and of course declined an invitation to it, which I received yesterday— I dined at home, and my mother dined with us— My father dined at Faneuil-Hall— There was also a party of young Federalists who dined at the Washington-Hotel, and sent me an invitation to spend a few minutes with them— But I knew none of them, and did not attend.— My father and mother returned to Quincy in the Evening, and took out our boy John with them— He has again been quite unwell for several days— There were some slight fire-works on the Common in the Evening.— I finished my 21st: Lecture.

5. Heard Mr: Pearce of Brookline at Mr: Emerson’s, the whole day.— My brother with his wife and child came in from Quincy this afternoon— Mrs: Adams is going to-morrow to Haverhill— My brother returned to Quincy, and took with him Caroline Johnson, who is going to spend a week at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s.— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 115 and 116. which concludes the fifth volume of his works; but I could find no time this day to write.

6. At 9 O’Clock this morning I met the Commissioners on the Mill-Pond—and Mr: H. G. Otis and Mr: Peck the agents of the Corporation— We sat untill after 12 at Noon discussing with them their proposals and ours, and endeavouring to meet them upon terms— Adjourned to 4. in the afternoon— At 12 There was an adjourned meeting of the Hopkins Trustees—which I attended— We received a letter from Mr: Jonn: Jackson, declining the Office of Treasurer— And after some deliberation we chose Mr: W. Smith Treasurer— The meeting was adjourned after 2 O’Clock— I had barely time to come home and dine; and at 4. O’Clock attended again the meeting of the town’s Commissioners— The town-meeting which was to receive our report was adjourned to the 8th: instt:—but as we cannot then be ready, it was agreed that it should again be adjourned; and that Judge Davis and myself should be a sub-committee to agree with Mr: Otis on the form of the papers to be drawn— The substance of the agreement being concluded. We sat untill about 7.

7. Part of the forenoon I was engaged in renewing and settling my note to I. P. Davis.— Mr: Boylston dined with us, and immediately after dinner I went out with him to Neponset Bridge, where a meeting of the Directors was held— Mr: Niles was with us, and made his propositions that we should help him build a bridge and make a road, which he supposed would be advantageous to us— All the Directors were present, and voted not to take any portion of that undertaking upon the Company— I had intended after the meeting to go with Mr: Boylston to my father’s—but we found it so late when the business was done that we had not time— We returned immediately to Boston; and it was almost 9 when I reached home— I went to the town Clerk, to publish the banns between Mr: Buchanan and Caroline.

8. Rode out with Mrs: Adams, and spent the day at my father’s in Quincy. We took George with us— The ride was too great an exertion for Mrs: Adams in her present situation, and after our return she was quite unwell. The club was at Mr: Cobb’s—where I went and pass’d an hour— It was pretty well attended— Mr: T. Greenleaf— Caroline Johnson, and the two young men who are students with my brother, dined with us at my father’s— I settled accounts with him—

9. The numerous interruptions, with which I have been diverted from my professional business the last seven days have almost entirely suspended my proper labours— I returned to them this day and wrote the customary quantity of my 22d: Lecture; which I ought before this to have finished, but which I have little more than commenced— I had this day a debate somewhat warm, with Mr: John Lowell, at the Suffolk Insurance Office— But was the greatest part of the day at home.

Chesapeake Affair (1807)

div.p: 10. Walked up to Cambridge with John Smith— Read my 21st: Lecture; which as I had expected appeared to give satisfaction— Among my hearers was Judge Thacher and Mr: Smith, the chief Justice of New-Hampshire— They also with me attended the Lecture of Dr: Waterhouse, which immediately followed mine, and was upon the scale of being— We all dined at the Drs: after I had spent an hour in the Library— At 2. I attended the Declamation in the Chapel—it was good, but not equal to the last— One of the Speakers appeared again with the aid of a prompter; of which I strongly express’d my disapprobation— Dr: Waterhouse immediately after the declamation took me into Boston in his Chaise— A Meeting of the Citizens of Boston, and the neighbouring towns had been call’d to meet at the State-House, to consider the late outrageous attack of the British ship Leopard upon our frigate Chesapeake, and to adopt resolutions concerning it— I had been desirous of a regular town-meeting, but this was utterly discouraged by the federalists, and the other party were afraid of calling it— This meeting was not numerous, and consisted almost entirely of friends to the present Administration— Mr Morton urged me to act as Moderator, but I declined— Mr: Gerry at length arrived and was chosen chairman— Mr: Morton Secretary— A Committee of seven was immediately chosen to draft Resolutions and report them to the meeting. B. Bidwell. Dr: Jarvis. B. Austin— G. Blake. T. J. Skinner. P. Morton, and myself— We went into the Senate-chamber— G. Blake had got his Resolutions all drawn; and the Committee had obviously discussed them before— I objected to one of the Resolutions, which was immediately given up— Objections were also made to a long preamble which Blake had drawn, and which was also abandoned. A shorter preamble was also agreed to drawn by B. Austin— We then unanimously reported the Resolutions, which were unanimously adopted; and the meeting adjourned in perfect order. I pass’d the Evening at home— My brother dined at my house; and returned to lodge here this Night— John Smith went out to Quincy. Mrs: Adams has been very ill; but is recovering.

11. My brother went this day to Haverhill, with his brother in Law, Foster— John Smith came for him this morning from Quincy, but returned alone at Night— Dr: Welsh and his Lady were here a short time this Evening— I was at the Insurance-Offices before dinner— J. Phillips told me I should have my head taken off, for apostasy, by the federalists— I have indeed expected to displease them, but could not help it— My Sense of duty shall never yield to the pleasure of a party.— I am this day forty years of age, and when I reflect how much in the course of that period I have received in blessings from Heaven, and how little I have returned in benefit to the world, I can neither look back nor forwards with any satisfaction.

12. Heard Dr: Kirkland this forenoon, and Mr: Emerson after dinner— Mrs: Adams also went in the afternoon— The Sermon was on the character of Samuel, and address’d particularly to the children of the Society.— George paid much attention to it, and recollected a great part of its substance afterwards— I bathed with him this Evening at the alms-house wharf.— I began reading the 6th: Volume of Tillotson’s works— And read his Sermons 117 and 118. which are a defence of Christianity. I was so much engaged in bringing up arrears of this diary the remainder of the day, that I had no time left for my lecture, which is languishing.— I met Mr: J. Gardner this morning; who had a son the 4th: of this month— He told me I was said to have changed sides in politics, and mentioned some falsehoods in circulation against me—

13. Mr: John Peck came this morning to my house and requested me to call at Judge Davis’s at 4. in the afternoon to examine the draft of a deed to be executed between the Town and the Mill Corporation which Mr: Otis has prepared. I accordingly went, but we found upon examination that it did not meet the ideas of the Commissioners and we agreed to have another meeting of them called to-morrow afternoon— As I was returning home Dr: Kilham called me in to his lodgings in Summer Street, and I had half an hour of Conversation with him— Walk’d in the Mall, and afterwards called at the Athenaeum to look in to Vattel— My brother returned from Haverhill, and lodges at our house— The heat was this day very oppressive. I finished my 22. lecture.

14. Caroline Johnson returned from Quincy this morning with Mr: T. Greenleaf junr.—who dined with us, and with whom my brother in the afternoon went home— Charlotte Welsh also dined with us— At 4 this afternoon I attended a meeting of the Commissioners of the Mill-Pond— Mr: Otis’s draft of an Indenture was not accepted, and a new proposal to be made to the Mill-Corporation was agreed upon— I afterwards spent an hour at the Insurance Office— By losing the afternoon I wrote less than my usual task; but began my 23. lecture.

15. The board of health this day went down upon their usual annual visit to Rainsford’s island— They had sent me an invitation to be of the company, but I could not in consistency with my duties spare the day— I sent an excuse, and spent the whole day at home writing with my most laborious application. In the Evening I attended the club, at judge Davis’s— It was not very full— Mr: Niles of Vermont— Judge Sedgwick, and Mr: Wendell Davis were there. Had some conversation with Mr: Tyng.

16. There was a town-meeting this morning at 10. to receive and act upon a communication received from the Committee of Correspondence at Norfolk— Mr: J. C. Jones was chosen moderator— I was appointed with Mr: H. G. Otis Mr: Gore, Dr: Jarvis, Coll: T. H. Perkins, Mr Mason, Dr: Eustis, Mr: Jones and Dr: Warren. a Committee to draft resolutions on the occasion— Mr: Mason had four Resolutions drawn up, which were adopted unanimously with some Amendments— Mr: Otis offered a fifth to act as a call upon the Government for the protection of a naval force. This however was objected to by Dr: Jarvis and myself, and was withdrawn by Mr: Otis— The Resolutions were then reported, and unanimously accepted by the town, and the meeting dissolved— I was afterwards an hour at the Insurance office, which consumed the remainder of the Morning— After dinner I wrote upon my lecture. Spent the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s. Mr: S. A. Otis and his family were there— Charlotte Welsh came home with us.

div.p: 17. John Smith came in from Quincy this morning— Attended my lecture at Cambridge, and returned at Night— I walked to and from Cambridge, although the weather was very warm— Delivered at 10 O’Clock my 22d. Lecture— Spent a couple of hours in the Library— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Attended the Declamation at 2— The Sophomore Class finished, almost as well as they began— At 4. O’Clock in the afternoon I met the Commissioners of the Mill-Pond, and we sat untill 7. we treated with Mr: Otis and Mr: Peck, but came to no final conclusion— Agreed to meet again Monday Morning at 9. Caroline and Charlotte Welsh spend the Evening at Mr S. A. Otis’s.

18. Day of Excessive heat Thermometer at 94.— I spent it at home in writing untill the Evening— Finished my Lecture 23.— Charlotte Welsh left us this Morning— In the Evening I called at Shaw’s Office, but he was not there— I met Mr: Hall and Mr: Lloyd, and had some Conversation with them.

19. Mrs: Adams was very ill, all last Night and the whole of this day.— I heard Mr:ofpreach, at Mr. Emerson’s, the whole day— George went with me this afternoon— On returning home I found Mr: Buchanan
who had just arrived from Baltimore— He spent the Evening here— I bathed at the alms-house wharf— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 119 and 120— But found no time for writing.

20. At 9. this morning, I met the Commissioners on the Mill-Pond, and we had also Mr: Otis and Mr: Peck with us, to treat for the Mill-Corporation— We finally agreed upon an Instrument to be drawn, and Judge Davis and myself were again appointed a sub-committee to agree with them on a draft of Indentures— On looking over again that to which he had agreed in terms Otis receded in a material point and declared he would never agree to it unless differently modified— At which I took fire and moved to report that we could not agree— Judge Davis being a common cooler for us both, pass’d over the article, and we finally determined to leave it for further consideration by the Commissioners— Otis though systematically a man of great politeness, is quick, and hasty in temper, and at such times very irritating in his manner— Without his accomplishment, I am afflicted with his infirmity, and we catch like fire and tinder— We sat untill near one O’Clock; and I then spent half an hour at the Insurance Office, and half an hour at Mr: Hall’s Office— There I met Dr: Eustis, who conversed with me again on the Mill-Pond business— In the afternoon I called at Mr: Emerson’s house, but he was dining at Mr: Woodward’s— I was obliged to decline an invitation to dine with him also.— I met Mr: Emerson, and Dr: Welsh this Evening in the Mall— Mr: Buchanan dined & spent the Evening with us.

21. My Mother and Sister, with her family came in this afternoon from Quincy— But my father did not come— Nor my brother and his wife. I called on Mr: Cooper the town Clerk, and received from him the Certificate— Between Eight and Nine this Evening, Mr: Andrew Buchanan of Baltimore, was married by Mr: Emerson to my wife’s Sister, Carolina, Virginia, Marylanda Johnson.— Our family from Quincy— Dr: Welsh and his Lady & Daughters, Mr: Joseph Hall, Mr: W. S. Shaw were the Company present— We had a house full of Company at Night.

22. I spent the day in my chamber, writing as steadily as was in my power— This afternoon my brother and his wife came into Town, and my Mother and Sister, with our little John returned to Quincy— This Evening we had a small company of young Ladies and Gentlemen, who danced untill about midnight— Dr: Welsh & Mr: S. A. Otis’s families were also here— We had a light Supper, but were somewhat crowded for want of Room— John Smith went out to Quincy last Evening after the wedding, but returned this day.— We returned this Evening to our own chambers.

23. Rose late this morning— The former part of the day confined us to the house with Rain.— I attended at Noon, and at 4. P.M. the meeting of the Hopkins Trustees— Mr: Smith declined accepting the Office of Treasurer. Mr: Caleb Gannett was chosen a member, and Treasurer— Judge Davis shewed me his draft of the Report from the Commissioners of the Mill-Pond; and proposes a meeting to-morrow afternoon— I was a short time before Noon attending on the Session of the Supreme Court—which sits in the Land Office at the New State-House— I am now as studious as Circumstances will permit, but unavoidably lose much of my time. Louisa Smith, and my Sister’s daughter Caroline this afternoon returned to Quincy.

div.p: 24. I walk’d to Cambridge— Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan, with Charlotte Welsh and John Smith followed in a Hack. At 10. O’Clock I read my lecture 23.— The Chapel was almost full of Company.— My friends after visiting the library returned to Boston— I remained in the library untill the hour of Commons— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— At 2 O’Clock I attended the Declamation— The Junior Class began, but the speaking was quite indifferent. I returned to Boston in the Stage, and attended a meeting of the Commissioners of the Mill-Pond. We executed the Deed which is to be submitted to the Town for Ratification— Evening at home.— Mr: & Mrs: B— at Dr: Welsh’s.

25. Mrs: T. Greenleaf of Quincy, and Mr: Hall were here this morning— At Noon I went out with Mr: Buchanan to Quincy and dined at my father’s with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society, and several other Gentlemen.— Mr: Shaw came out with Mr: Kendall, an English Gentleman travelling in this Country.— After viewing the extensive prospects from the hill opposite my father’s house, I returned in the Evening with Mr: Buchanan to Boston—

26. Went this morning with Mr: Buchanan to the Stone chapel, where Mr: Sewall read prayers and a Sermon of Blair— In the afternoon we all heard Mr: Emerson— Mr: & Mrs: B. and J. Smith dined at Dr: Welsh’s— Mr: Smith and Dr: Welsh and their families spent the Evening with us— I finished this day my lecture 24— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 121. and 122.— I have been this day ten years married.

27. I was unable to begin the first sketch of my lecture 25. though I employed the forenoon chiefly in preparing for it— Dr: Waterhouse called upon me this morning— Dined with Mr: Buchanan, and J. Smith, at Mr: Emerson’s. Mr: Shaw—Mr: W. Smith—Coll: Bradford and a Mr: Lee were there— We went after dinner to Fort-Hill, and to Faneuil-Hall.— Spent the Evening at Mr: W. Smith’s.

28. Began the first draught of my lecture 25.— I was the first part of the day employed abroad— It was then cold— But in the afternoon and Evening, was very warm and showery:— Dr: Kirkland here, to speak respecting young Mr: Everett.

29. The day was entirely devoted to Company— Mr: Boylston, Mr: Emerson, Mr: Kendall, Mr: Shaw, Mr: Jos: Hall. Mr: Rogers, Dr: Waterhouse and Dr: Welsh dined with us— We had a very social party, and left the Table about Dusk. I was in the Evening at the Club at Dr: Dexter’s— Mr: Michaux and a Mr: Godon were there. Michaux is collecting materials for a Supplement to his father’s work on the Oaks of Carolina, and Mr: Godon comes with a letter from Mr: Peck, recommending him as a chymist and mineralogist.— Mrs: Peabody and her daughter were here this morning— And also Mrs: T. B. Adams and Caroline Smith— J. S. went out with them.

30. Mr: and Mrs: Buchanan with Charlotte Welsh, went and pass’d this day at Quincy. They returned before Night, and spent the day Eveg at Miss Gray’s.— I pass’d the day at home, as studiously as I found possible the day after a festival— Bathed in the Evening with George— Mrs: Adams was unwell the whole day; but in the Evening was so ill, we sent for Dr: Welsh— Mr: Townsend was here this afternoon.

div.p: 31. The Selectmen went this day upon their usual annual party to Deer-Island— I had an invitation to go with them, but could not attend, being obliged to attend on my duties at Cambridge— Mr: Buchanan had also been invited, but was so ill all last Night and this morning that he was obliged to confine himself to the house. John Smith came in early this morning from Quincy. I walk’d to and from Cambridge— Read my 24th: Lecture at 10— Heard a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse immediately after mine— Spent an hour in the Library— Dined at Dr: W.’s— Attended the Declamation at 2— The Speakers were few, and not very good— I reached home between 3. and 4. much fatigued— Mr: J. Hall and Miss Gray were here in the Evening— Dr: Welsh called— Mrs: Buchanan and Charlotte Welsh pass’d the Evening at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— I was there about half an hour and came home with Mrs: B.— Mrs: Adams and Mr: Buchanan were this Evening much recovered.

div.p: Day. Rise irregularly between 6 and 8.— Read and hear George in French untill 9. Breakfast— Read or write untill 12. or 1. Walk in town—to read Newspapers and hear news— Return home to dinner between 2. and 3. After dinner again in my chamber untill dusk— Walk an hour in the Mall or elsewhere— Sup between 9 and 10 at Night— Bed about 11.— Fridays at Cambridge— This is the regular course; but the exceptions are more numerous than the rule. My house and my Time have been beset with Company the greatest part of the month, and a variety of occupations abroad has absorbed a large portion of my hours— My Cambridge duties have never been intermitted and this day the Senior Class leaves College— I have declined all dissipation and invitations of amusement when possible, but still waste Time inexcusably.— George’s lessons the last fortnight have been lost.
